definition: to take the big picture into consideration (idiom)/to work for the benefits of all
surname Gu
to look after/to take into consideration/to attend to
all/whole/entire/every/complete
surname Quan
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
office/situation/classifier for games: match, set, round etc

sentences.english: To our disappointment, he fails to take the whole situation into consideration.
sentences.chinese: 使我們失望的是他不顧全大局。

sentences.english: We should keep the tail from wagging the dog to deal with all the things.
sentences.chinese: 我們在處理任何事情的時候都要記得顧全大局。

sentences.english: To our disappointment he refused to take the whole situation into account.
sentences.chinese: 使我們失望的是他不顧全大局。

sentences.english: Sacrifice yourself, on-time, loyal to argue, is from.
sentences.chinese: 犧牲小我，顧全大局，爭論無益，忠恕是從。

sentences.english: You talk about, you know, being able to prioritize and manage.
sentences.chinese: 你要談到的是，你知道，你能夠合理統籌，顧全大局。

sentences.english: People that are in love tend to look beyond minor annoyances to the bigger picture.
sentences.chinese: 沐浴在愛中的人會顧全大局而不會計較一些小缺陷。

sentences.english: You often remind yourself of the "bigger picture. ""
sentences.chinese: 你經常提醒自己顧全大局。

sentences.english: We must take the overall situation into account.

definition: lit. to attend to one thing and lose sight of another (idiom)/fig. to be unable to manage two or more things at once/cannot pay attention to one thing without neglecting the other
to assess one's income and spend accordingly (idiom); to live within one's means/You can only spend what you earn.
power struggle
to gang up for personal interest (idiom)/to form a clique
old: to reap the consequences of one's words (idiom, from Mencius); modern: to go back on one's word/to blow hot and cold/to contradict oneself/inconsistent
to obstruct/to impede
magnanimous (idiom); generous
open the net on one side (idiom); let the caged bird fly/to give one's opponent a way out/lenient treatment
(of friends or partners) to share both the honor and the disgrace (idiom)
to nip in the bud (idiom)
selfless/impartial
each sticks to his own version (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
proud and arrogant
conflict/internal strife/dissension
impoverished/backward both economically and culturally
to spare no effort (idiom); to do one's utmost
